SENT.plain: We report a case of non-fluent conduction aphasia
The patient was a 59-year-old right-handed male
He suffered from aphasia after a left internal carotid artery occlusion
MRI study revealed subcortical lesions in the left inferior frontal gyrus and cortical lesion in the anterior part of the left insular gyrus and the left postcentral gyrus
The patient showed good comprehension of words and daily conversation but had a common difficulty in the following tasks; naming of pictures, repetition of words, reading of kanji and kana letters
In these tasks, the phonological output of the patient contained many literal paraphasias and there was a tendency that errors appeared more in the posterior portion of a target word
We analyzed the position of errors in the target word on word repetition tasks
The result confirmed the above observation
We speculate that the length of a target word may have played a critical rote in this patient's repetition capability
